text:
Advocates Want NYC to Drop Criminal Penalties for Minor Offenses to Protect Immigrants They argue that immigrants who have criminal records for nonviolent offenses could be deported By @coryramey Updated Feb. 21, 2017 8:41 p.m. ET 
Immigration advocates on Tuesday urged New York City to impose civil rather than criminal penalties for certain nonviolent offenses to protect immigrants who could be deported if they have a criminal record. 
The city cooperates with federal immigration officials on deportation only when immigrants commit serious crimes. But advocates and public defense attorneys said such measures arenâ€™t enough, especially in light of memos released Tuesday by the Department of Homeland Security that tightened deportation rules.
